38723614.review:
A solid fairytale-like horror game with unique mechanics (i.e. the save function and placing candles on the ground to light dark areas) ans well as some gorgeous pixel art and bleep-bloop versions of classical music. Every choice you make has a big impact on how the game later plays out. It's filled with puzzles that manage to be challenging without once seeming impossible or frustratingly unintuitive. The story is not extremely complicated, like a fairytale, but it still manages to be interesting and have a surprising amount of depth to it. There's a lot to explore and many mysteries to piece together, which I enjoyed. There also aren't really any jumpscares, which is nice because the game manages to create a creepy and intense atmosphere without them. The game overall is pretty short, about eight hours or so, which I think was pretty good considering its price. It seemed like just the right amount of time for this sort of game. 

The only downsides I can think of to this game is that the protagonist walks at only one speed, which is rather slow and could annoy players (although I think he's intentionally slow for the stealth aspect of the game...plus it makes the game more challenging) and that the save function, which relies on throwing a limited amount of gold coins into a well, can occasionally be stressful and frustrating -- though once again, it made the player's choices matter a lot more and made the game more challenging, so I wasn't too bothered by it. 

Since the game was pretty hard, every puzzle I managed to complete felt very rewarding -- by the end of the game, I felt like even though this game kicked my ass, I managed to kick its ass back. It was great. 

I highly recommend getting this game if you're even remotely interested.

38453037.review:
Me ha encantado el juego y me ha enganchado. Es un survival horror de 8bits que más que enfocado en los sustos se enfoca en la tensión que produce la incapacidad del persona. Y lo consigue a pesar de la estética de 8 bits que tiene usando una mecánica de sonidos y oscuridad.

Después de eso, las mecánicas jugables son sencillas, consiste en pequeños puzzles no muy complicados (excepto 1) y un pequeña jugabilidad de sigilo y esconderse de los enemigos.

Lo siguiente, no es un juego difícil y cuya dificultad radica en no poder guardar cuando quieres y que si te descuidas es posible que llegues a un callejón sin salida teniendo que cargar. Avisado estáis! Sed cuidadosos con algunos puzzles!.

Una cosa que puede echar hacia atrás es el ritmo lento del juego, un único ritmo. Actualmente los juegos ofrecen que los personajes corran que va en sincronía a cómo va la sociedad (siempre corriendo hacía los lugares, haciendo las cosas, en vez de vivir más pausado), eso provoca que dé la sensación de juego lento cuando comprobamos que Hans es lento de pelotas. Pero luego una vez que entra en el castillo se diluye por la mecánica de tensión y sigilo del castillo dicha anteriormente.

El argumento mola. A mí me ha gustado y es bastante completo para el juego que es. No sobreexplica, no son 2 detalles insignificantes (el estilo epistolar para contarte cosas del lore está muy bien y ya que cada uno que gaste el tiempo que crea en investigar). A destacar las escenas visuales: de gran calidad y cuyo toque retro queda muy bien.  Luego los escenarios tienen grandes detalles de animación: los topos, conejos, etc.

Cosas que hubiera preferido: La estética retro ya huele, hubiera preferido unos mejores gráficos, con tener los pixeles de un Chrono Trigger (por decir uno) me hubiera gustado mucho más y no se hubiera perdido el toque retro.

Pero en definitiva un juego recomendable si estáis cansado de tantos disparos: Son 5h de duracción.

38299250.review:
"Party, party, grotesque party!". This what will say the zombie head of a goatherd.

Count Lucanor is a little weird gem, a dark fairytale where the free exploration of a mysterious castle and the interaction with different characters allow the discovery of alternative scenes and endings. The gameplay is simple but the exploration keeps high the interest. The game is also short, but with a lot of replayability. 

To be a "retro coming to age fairytale" this game can be really disturbing, with blood, guts and few but creepy enemies. Horror fan will surely love Count Lucanor more than would expect.

The most interesting features of this game are the characters and their evolution, really creepy and unsettling. A naked man thinks to be a pig transformed in human, while the decapitated head of a goatherd is using his two demonic goats as hitmen. Yes, you read right, killer hellish goats.

If you are curious, here a quick character analysis: https://surrealandcreepy.wordpress.com/2017/12/13/count-lucanor-hellish-goats-disembodied-goatherds-and-though-choices/

38152067.review: What a great logic game of the "adorably creepy" kind. If you like solving puzzles set into a simple, but gripping story, this game is definitely for you. Some seemingly small choices can change the game entirely, which increases the replay value. If puzzle games are your thing, go for this.

38070906.review: The Count Lucanor is a very memorable but sadly short game. It's in a simplistic pixel style with really good animations, though the gameplay aesthetic could be a bit better. Multiple endings, fun achievements, and suspenseful gameplay make this a great game, but the small gameplay issues and the shortness makes it sadly not a top-tier game. I would reccomend it to lovers of puzzles, rpg's, gore fans, and anyone who seems interested!

38047665.review:
Описание The Count Lucanor завлекает игрока названиями знаменитых игр и своими ключевыми особенностями, но на поверку всё это оказывается скорее предвыборными обещаниями неумелого политика, чем реальным наполнением игры.

Игра повествует об эгоистичном мальчике Гансе, который устал жить в нищете, а потому в свой десятый день рождения он оставляет свою мать одну и отправляется в путешествие на поиски лучшей жизни, попутно забирая последние сбережения. Однако его путешествие вскоре прерывается, так как, очнувшись после попойки с пастухом, он обнаруживает, что от пастуха осталась лишь одна голова, милые козочки стали охочими до крови чудовищами, а все таблички предрекают Гансу скорейшую смерть. Здесь начинается хоррор-часть игры, здесь же она и закачивается. Просто посмотрите на [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1214063534]этот[/url] скриншот, здесь даже комментарии излишни. Спасаясь от монстров Ганс встречает загадочного духа, который приводит его в замок графа Луканора, ищущего наследника своих несметных богатств в лице человека, способного пройти одно маленькое испытание – угадать имя этого самого духа с помощью букв, разбросанных где-то по всему замку. Ганс, кстати, почему-то внезапно становится добрым и милым мальчиком без следа былого эгоизма. На этом моменте можно смело забыть про сюжет до самого конца, наслаждаясь такими чудесными местами для поиска букв, как, например, анальный проход человека-свиньи. Да и в конце сюжет даже не пытается удивить игрока, давая ему на выбор несколько мало чем отличающихся друг от друга концовок, из которых можно было бы смело слепить две полноценные. Ага, ничего от Silent Hill или Yume Nikki. ([spoiler]Если не считать того, что все наполнение замка построено из искаженных воспоминаний и фантазий героя[/spoiler]) Хорошее начало.

В игровом процессе ждать исполнения обещаний тоже не стоит, если для вас The legend of Zelda не про перемещение ящиков на кнопки и дурацкие головоломки с рычагами, а Dark Souls не про надпись "You died". Игра построена на прохождении небольших комнат-испытаний, в каждой из которых игрока должна ждать одна из букв, причем ни одно из испытаний нисколько не запоминается, зато на них легко умереть, что подводит нас к другой важной особенности: в игре очень мало лечащих предметов, а за сохранения нужно платить золотыми монетами, которых в игре очень мало и их в приемлемом количестве можно получить лишь в качестве фекалий, вылетающих из задницы осла-единорога (что вообще не так с разработчиками?). Осел ест только яблоки, а игроку нужно умудриться не только их не съесть, но и надеяться, что осла не убьют местные монстры или же он сам не исчезнет, потому что игре так захотелось. Все это вынуждает игрока экономить предметы "на чёрный день" и проходить сразу несколько комнат без сохранений, рискуя умереть, что растягивает трёхчасовую игру по меньшей мере в ДВА РАЗА. Благо, что с ослом есть баг, позволяющий набить себе бесконечное количество монеток.

Монстров в игре всего три вида: козлы, которые двигаются немного быстрее героя, притягивающие к себе часовые и их глава, встреча с которым, скорее всего, будет летальна. Все они довольно тупоголовые и часто застревают рядом с проходами в комнаты, что делает стелс бесполезным, так как игроку не имеет смысла ждать и надеяться, что этот болванчик соизволит сдвинуться с места, да и монстры никогда не последуют за игроком в другую локацию, тем самым убивая все напряжение от встречи с ними. Выборы же подразделяются на правильные и неправильные, что влияет лишь на сложность прохождения очередной комнаты. Единственное, чем в действительности вдохновлялись разработчики – это сказки братьев Гримм. Причем под вдохновлением здесь подразумевается дословное копирование отдельных элементов.

Другим весьма грязным приёмом можно назвать видео на японском языке на странице в магазине, привлекающее определённую аудиторию людей, надеющихся получить хоть что-то похожее на упомянутых в описании "собратьев" из Страны восходящего солнца, когда на деле создатели родом из Испании.

[b]The Count Lucanor – далеко не плохая игра. Это просто заурядная адвенчура, навешавшая на себя множество ярлыков, которым не смогла соответствовать, но ведь все понимают, что случается с политиком, не оправдавшим ожиданий? Его рейтинг ПАДАЕТ.[/b]

38016377.review:
Impresionante este juego. Único y muy especial. La jugabilidad es bastante simple, mezcla entre aventura gráfica y survival horror en plan 8 bits (por llamarlo de alguna manera...) pero la gracia es la historia, la narrativa, lo oscuro y perturbador que rodea al título... Y para acabar, mencionar que hay pequeñas decisiones que afectan al juego.

Sea como fuere, punto por punto el juego es bueno, pero el conjunto, la historia y la experiencia en sí, es genial. Es una joyita escondida.

38005726.review:
Es un pequeño juego muy interesante. Una historia atrayente, un formato tipo cuento perfecto para un juego corto como este, que seguramente es su mayor pega, ya que en una tarde lo liquidas casi al 100% si eres completista.

En general le doy una valoración muy positiva, especialmente si lo consigues de oferta. 

El diseño artístico es muy bueno. Los gráficos podrían ser mejores (son muy 8-bit, un estilo 16-bit hubiese sido mas atractivo sin duda) pero suficientes.

La musica sin destacar demasiado esta bien elegida. Efectos de sonido y musica ambiental son buenos y te meten en el juego, y los efectos de sonido de los malos son bastante grimosillos.

La jugabilidad es simple pero muy efectiva, sin necesitar mas herramientas que las que el juego te da. Echo en falta un boton de correr que podría tener mecánicas interesantes , como hacer ruido para atraer mas a los enemigos a cambio de ir mas rápido, por ejemplo. Sobre todo una vez te has pasado ya el juego y quieres ir a completarlo, el caminar del personaje es muy lento. También podría ser interesante poder lanzar las castañas para hacer ruido y distraer a los enemigos, teniendo que elegir entre usarlas o comértelas.

Lo dicho, un juego sencillo muy bien realizado que cuenta una historia bastante inmersiva y que consigue dar mal rollo aún con su simpleza gráfica gracias a su historia y mecánicas. Eché en falta mas variedad en su jugabilidad y desarrollo y creo que se podría haber trabajado mas en crear una historia mas abierta para que los finales fuesen mas diferentes. Que sea tan lineal quita muchos incentivos para rejugarlo. Aún así, el juego merece la pena si lo que cuesta te parece un buen precio para jugar entre 5 a 8 horas aprox.

SPOILERS
[spoiler]
En la parte final del juego, cuando entras en "tu casa", me parece feo que el anillo de la serpiente no marque a tu "madre" como falsa, pudiendo resultar en otra forma de llevar esa trama a su final. 
Tampoco entendí la trama del gusano-mariposa, creo que esta metida un poco con calzador y que se podría haber encontrado una forma mejor de introducirla en el juego, o de generar un impacto con ello.
Que el cofre del patio te diga que se puede abrir con un candado de combinación y nunca te deje probar no me gustó. Creo que ese puzzle debería resolverse de otra forma, o dejarte la opción de probar a abrirlo, que es lo que esperaba al leer el cuadro de texto. Se vuelve confuso al no dare opción de abrirlo.
El espejo me parece otro objeto muy desaprovechado, ya que salvo su uso para la pista del piso de arriba no sirve para nada. Sería muy chulo que pudiese tener otro impacto en el juego mas adelante, como protegerte del camarlengo rojo o de los funcionarios, por ejemplo, si lo llevas equipado)
Me gusta mucho que el juego te ofrece la posibilidad de descubrir el nombre del asistente sin resolver los puzzles de las habitaciones. De los pocos momentos donde se te da una flexibilidad real.
En general creo que el juego tenía potencial para ser mucho menos lineal.
[/spoiler]

37950122.review:
Hans, un zagalete harto de su vida de campesino, decide huir en busca de aventuras y riquezas y, guiado por un duende tras una fatídica noche, acaba en el castillo del susodicho conde. Si supera la prueba, se le instruye, él heredará el título y sus riquezas, y tiene toda la noche para hacerlo. El desafío no podría ser más simple: adivinar el nombre del duende que sirve a Lucanor.

La gran virtud de El Conde Lucanor es que consigue engañar al jugador con mano experta y uno no se da cuenta de que le han manipulado hasta que se detiene a pensar. La historia es muy breve y se puede completar en una sentada, pero este rasgo que muchos considerarían un defecto es utilizado para, como si fuera un mago, trucarnos y hacernos creer que el mundo es más grande y rico de lo que realmente es. El castillo no es muy grande, pero la iluminación es pésima y toca ir colocando velas por el camino para evitar que al dar media vuelta se nos aparezca un sirviente con ganas de enseñarnos qué horrores se ocultan bajo su máscara. No es una experiencia agradable. Esto significa que hay que ir caminando con cautela, vigilando las esquinas, cuidando cuántas velas nos quedan y sobre todo escuchar y prestar atención. El ritmo pausado y la necesidad de ir y venir una y otra vez crean una sensación de que aún falta por explorar y, de hecho, hay todo un segundo piso que el guión no obliga a visitar pero que oculta secretos sobre su historia y mitología.

El Conde Lucanor sabe que su experiencia termina en unas horas y que hemos jugado a Dark Souls, y por eso nos da un jardín como nexo central, habitándolo con personajes que cambian a lo largo de la noche y nos vienen con sus peticiones y por favores, caprichos y trasfondos para intuir a esta gran historia de brujas, ladrones y cabezas cortadas que en realidad no existe más allá de unas pocas líneas. Si se abren las cortinas y se enciende la luz, resulta que este es un título más bien simplón y repetitivo, pero es un juego de manos. Hay secretos y opciones que revelan una inesperada segunda cara en la historia y un gusto por el engaño y malgastar esfuerzos por nada que, más que frustrar, llevan una carga de intencionalidad, como si desde Baroque Decay quisieran mantenernos alerta y recordarnos que porque sea un videojuego no tiene por qué funcionar tal y como queremos.

Hay una extraña creatividad en El Conde Lucanor. No es una historia compleja ni original, pero su fusión de culturas trae un aire fresco a una premisa gastada. Su interpretación del sigilo trae el diseño del survival horror moderno, el de esconderse y huir, y lo pone en un plano picado con gráficos píxel en 2D. Su sencillez y la forma en que la afronta, sin creerse más de lo que es pero confiando en sí mismo, lo convierten en una rara avis en el panorama de los indies que intentan mostrar grandes revelaciones y cambiar el mundo. El Conde Lucanor no lo pretende; es sólo esta historia de un chico que llega a un castillo y desde ahí el jugador decide cómo enfrentarse al desafío hasta llegar a uno de sus finales.

Nota: 8,5/10

37941707.review: Die Story ist gut durchdacht und spannend, die Figuren interesant und unterhaltsam, die Rätzel ganz lustig aber nicht zu schwer und die Spielmechanik passt echt gut zu all dem. War nach ca. 6 Stunden durch (ohne Pausen war einfach zu lustig) also ein gutes Spiel für zwischendurch.

37923088.review: The Count Lucanor is a mostly enjoyable horror tale that is only prevented from being a truly great game thanks to a couple of performance issues and relatively short duration. At its best, the game offers a surprisingly rich story, intriguing and genuinely creepy characters and surroundings, and enjoyable puzzle-based tasks to ponder over. The candle and saving systems add to the stress imposed by the castle, forcing you to choose between being safe in the present or keeping supplies for later on although a harder difficulty setting which provides less of these items could have worked wonders.If you’re looking for something a little bit different, this could well be the game for you.

36968147.review:
A fun little retro horror puzzler with some very nice animated cutscenes and in-game scenes. Going into it without any knowledge left me to assume that my choices in the beginning will effect the game later, which I replayed the beginning a few times until I was satisfied with my choices. After making those moral choices, you'll soon be able to explore the castle: encountering puzzles and death traps, collecting keys, and finding notes and clues you'll need to decide the best choice to make when the time comes.

Finished the game in around 3 to 4 hours and was able to unlock most of the endings due to the choices I made and clues I discovered. Even though I've got most of the endings, the achievements I haven't unlocked tell me I still have a few more things to discover, so there is some replay value. [spoiler] Oh, and there's a donkey that craps gold! XD [/spoiler]

36914773.review:
El conde de lucanor es un videojuego que personalmente recomiendo, es una obra que tiene especial afecto a los cuentos simples, tales como los que nos contaban antes, cuando eramos niños, y toma todo eso lo lo transforma en una pesadilla, rozando lo que seria un silent hill, transformando lo que creemos como normal/bueno en todo lo malo que se nos ocurra, la historia esta llena de misterios y personajes que no son muy predecibles, aunque a mi parecer deberian tener una pisca mas de dialogos.

La jugabilidad se podria considerar como jugar a las escondidas, basicamente se tienen escondites divididos por el escenario, enemigos vagando por el mismo, avisandonos de su precincia a base de un susurro, para tener mayor control de los mismos, se colocan velas para tener vision del mapa y evitar a los espectros.

Graficamente es un juego de estetica 8 bits que funciona siendo minimalista, y posee escenas cinematicas de PixelArt que son para quitarse el sombrero.

Sonoramente, el juego sabe como transmitir sentimientos casi a la perfeccion y acompañar jugablemente.

Como extra quiero agregar que el juego posee varios finales, hice 3 o 4 y si no me equivoco el juego tiene 2 o 3 mas, todo de acuerdo a nuestras decisiones y/o usos de objetos especiales.

Como conclusion; un juego redondo que vale la pena para los que lo vayan a conseguir, con rebaja o sin ella.

The story is quite short, however there's so much more to explore and there are plenty of hidden gems. It's not very scary but this game had me sitting on the edge of my seat. The atmosphere is eerie but charming and the best part was the goat farmer. 

One mechanic that I and many others weren't too fond of was that there's no autosave or save-whenever-you-want from the menu type of option. You must save via an NPC and it requires currency, but I think that adds to the charm of the game because it allows you to face your mistakes head on, rather than knowing that there's a safety cushion.

36695386.review:
The Count Lucanor is a great spooky game, which proves you do not need big cool Graphic to make a spooky game. But its story time now. 

You play as Hans, a poor young boy who lives with his mom near the woods. On his tenth birthday he has neither presents nor sweets to eat on this day, which gets him upset at that and being poor, so he decides to leave home for good and seek Adventure and his fortune. But he gets more than he bargains for when he sees the kobold.

Now what I like about this game, well first I like the Pixel Graphics, again like I said this with other game like it, proves you do not need big cool Graphics to make a great game.

I liked the story; you can definitely see the inspiration for were this game come from, like old fairy tale/grim brothers, to more modern ones like Legend of Zelda and Silent Hill. 

Even the 16 bit music I all so liked is from Johann Sebastian Bach. If you don’t know who that is he was a German composer and musician born in 1685 and died in 1750.

I liked the characters they were interesting, my fav being Giulia. 

Now for the things that could have made the game better. Finding out more about Count Lucanor. I mean we get the idea about him, but it would have been nice to get a diary about him and especially his daughter.

Now with that done, The Count Lucanor is a good solid spooky game with a good story, good music, and some good scares too. So if you don’t care about big cool Graphic or if a game is triple A this game could be for you.

36544004.review:
This is an otherwise excellent pixel-graphics adventure game which is brought down by a single major flaw – the speed of our hero.

Despite the fact that the castle he’s exploring is chock-filled with all manner of eldritch horrors, the best our hero can manage is a slow gambol away from the terrors that pursue him – and pursue him they will! There are several places where you can (un)intentionally unleash/wake demonic beings who will then pursue you with unnatural zeal, blithely stepping over traps (which, of course, do not hurt them) in their quest to take a chunk out of your head. And, of course, they’ll _keep_ going after you until you either complete the room or reload from an earlier save.

There’s like a dozen different endings and a couple of different paths that you can take, but given that I managed to screw myself out of one of the items I’d need to get most of them (note: you do this to yourself in the first ~10 minutes of gameplay) I’m not putting up with going through the entire game again to see the rest of them.

Verdict: It was worthwhile as part of a bundle (i.e.: basically free), but I don’t know that I’d recommend it at $9.99 – perhaps on sale.

36233512.review:
标签：像素风格、恐怖，中世纪幻想、轻微猎奇、黑暗童话、8bit音乐、解谜、多结局、官方诚意汉化。
标签中绝大多数的都是我所喜爱的，非常开心的品味了这道佳肴。
[h1]犹如读一遍格林童话旧版一样[/h1]
游戏里参入了些西方文化中比较诸为人知的要素，例如：为什麽只有羊成敌人，红衣主管的强大，游戏的名字由来等，有兴趣可以去社区的一篇指南《卢卡诺伯爵中的一些小细节》中看看，传送门：http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1183030822
游戏体验中大部分的恐惧感来源于自我的联想，游戏对于血腥残酷部分刻画的其实并不多，并且几乎没有惊吓的部分，帮我省了洗衣物的时间。
游戏整体难度很低，机关稀散，敌人攻击能力低下，谜题简单，不用看攻略大多数的人也能轻松通关并打通绝大部分结局，只有少数的分支剧情需要读档来探索完成。
音效较优秀，能较好的配合场景。
解锁全成就可以体验所有的剧情，成就难度低，成就党一本满足。
剧情一般，有一定的起伏，正常流程就可以了解故事世界原貌，算是及格级别。
较为优秀的亮点：营造的恐怖氛围，人物的刻画。
总评：原价入也不算亏的一部解谜像素风游戏，较为优秀的恐怖氛围以及微量血腥和没有惊吓的设定让玩家游玩过程中充满了紧张和好奇，对于人物的刻画简洁且精准，多结局恰到好处的收官也能让人尽兴。

（部分涉及剧透的游戏小TIP，想自我探索的可以不看）
[spoiler]主角那么可爱，底下可是有大宝贝的！[/spoiler]
[spoiler]游戏内道具资源是足够的，正常使用即可[/spoiler]
[spoiler]BOSS不强，而且“人不犯我，我不犯人”[/spoiler]
[spoiler]不管你帮不帮助开头老穷搓，都可以正常打开所有结局[/spoiler]

36176831.review:
(Spoiler warning, just so any readers can't say I didn't warn them)

I really wanted to recommend this game, but there are a few infuriating mechanics that prevent me from doing so. I'll give the game props for having an original setting and being able to be unsettling with pixel art (which is something not a lot of people can do). The characters were interesting enough to keep me at least a bit invested, but they weren't anything phenominal.

What makes me unable to recommend The Count Lucanor are three things: the monster AI, a mechanic involving Hans himself, and the means of obtaining the ending. The story is also kind of a trainwreck, but with Steam's new character limit on reviews, I don't know if I'll be able to go into that.

First, the endings themselves. In order to reach any of them, you need to learn or guess the Kobold's name. The game has an invisible time limit that, if you take too long to get to the second floor, you will not able able to trigger the only part of the game in which you learn the kobold's name. You will have to spend hours of guesswork or simply look it up in order to actually progress. This is a game that heavily focuses on puzzles an exploration, this kind of genre almost always expects you to take your time. You can get to the upper floors faster with the conveniences you can get by gimping yourself at the beginning of the game. I had no qualms parting with the cane and couldn't have possibly expected the merchant to steal two of my coins. But this is a game where if you do take damage, you take a lot of it at once. So it's kind of difficult to part with the cheese you keep at the beginning. I still had the chestnuts, yeah, and I know now you can go back and get bread from your table. But that's the problem: I know that NOW. Not to mention your means of getting enough gold to get the golden key within the time limit randomly vanishes. The game seems to give a whole lot of signals throughout indicating that a guide is necessary, and it's next to impossible to currently find one. Any game that requires a guide is not a good game.

Second, Hans himself and the AI of the hallway monsters. His character certainly isn't bad, but why is it that he's unable to run from monsters despite clearly being shown to be a physically active child? It would have helped in a lot of situations with the monsters that roam the hallways refusing to go away and leaving me stuck with the only option being "risk taking damage because Hans is so damned slow".

I could spend more time taking apart parts of the game that truly infuriated me, but sadly Steam reviews have a smaller character limit than they used to. If you want a TL;DR, then just know this: there are better horror games than The Count Lucanor. It looks good, and it has a strong start, but there are mechanics and many other little things that simply make this game not worth playing. I honest to god wish I could refund this.

36131726.review:
[h1]A charming puzzle horror game carried primarily on its beautiful pixel art and bewitching soundtrack. While its puzzles have decent diversity, the stealth aspects and story serves their purpose but ultimately are deceptively shallow. Recommended for fans of stealth and atmosphere, but look elsewhere for something difficult or lengthy.[/h1]

The general exploration of the castle is centered around stealth which keeps the game's focused squarely on its well-designed puzzles. Very few of the puzzles have repeat solutions, impressive for the pixelized limitations, though some rooms are made too easy through seemingly innocuous methods. Similarly, the difficulty of exploring the castle and avoiding enemies drops dramatically once the game is understood, furthered by a lack of enemy variety and a surprising simplicity of the game's more threatening foes. So while the gameplay feels more like a means to an end, some fine tuning and a few additions could have made this an indie darling.

Its story is charming and dissonant with its heavy influence of folklore and fairy tales. It rides a fine balance between its dark horror aesthetics and childish sense of adventure and wonder with its setting and aesthetics. Unfortunately, the actual details of the story fall short of its design despite a few interesting moments of characterizing side characters. Some characters and lore elements could've been fleshed out more to give more life to its world, particularly its multiple endings had plenty of untapped potential to further the world instead of feeling like shallow epilogues.

If you're wanting this game, its art style and sound design are probably why and for good reason. The beautiful chiptune renditions of Bach's more haunting melodies set a perfect tone for the experience as a whole, the sounds of the monsters make them seem more terrifying than their patterns let on, and its pixel art cutscenes are breathtaking. Most of the items and characters are well designed and distinct despite its pixel art limitations, though the more Atari-esque style can make most of the humanoid characters offputting with an oddly lankey look to them due to their arms and legs being only a single pixel wide. And despite a general strength of the horror elements, some of them can come off as rather on the nose and trying a bit too hard.

This game is ultimately marred more by details rather than a greater image, which I find to be very forgivable in a developer's first game. I'd advise keeping an eye on Baroque Decay's future titles as they show impressive promise in understanding core tenants of horror that many developers frequently get wrong or simply forget. For similar games, I can recommend Claire, Lone Survivor, and Stray Cat Crossing.

Ганс на первом же повороте своего приключения, как и свойственно наивным детям (людям), раздаёт все свои нужные вещи первым встречным, оставшись практическими с пустыми карманами. 36116767.review:
A true masterpiece, The Count Lucanor presents the story of Hans, a 10 year old boy that runs from home to find his fortune. Initially, I must say I was hesitant about buying it, but hell if it wasn't worth it.

From truly complex 2D graphics to an interesting story and a medium difficulty that can be sometimes challenging, The Count Lucanor has it all. The mysteries of this game are really hard to solve and make you want to keep going till the end. Some of you may ask : what do you have to do in this game? Why, find the kobold's name,of course, I thought. But it isn't as easy as it seems...

I'd spoil you a bit and tell you more about the Horror tag, but it would just ruin your experience. The plot develops in a nice way, there's even a day-night cycle and the characters are all well thought. Take care though : you need attention and skill at finding secrets to have it easy with this game. It has quite a good replay value having 5 different endings and a way longer gameplay than I imagined ( spent 6 hours for my first and only run). Before going to the pros and cons, I must say this game is a true work of art and that it inspired me to continue developing a game I work on since a few weeks. If it ever gets released, this game is one of the games that made it possible.

Pros :
-Well-thought characters
-Plot develops nicely
-Day-Night cycle
-Can be challenging
-Interesting mysteries
-Good graphics
-Hard Puzzles
-Good Soundtrack
-Giulia's jumps <3

Cons :
-The Save System : some of you might find this weird, but the save system requires a coin for a save. it's not as bad as I initially thought since it makes the game a bit more challenging and there's more than enough coins for it. I've already managed to buy everything from the shop and make 2-3 saves. I personally don't find anything wrong with the save system, but if you are the type of person that saves often, this game isn't for you.

36113028.review:
The Count Lucanor feels like a fairy tale.  Not one of these children-audience-only and listen-to-your-heart boring bullshit you see most of the time in television. Instead, it's much closer to these weird, unsettling stories from hundreds of years ago, where blood, violence and fear were common and served creating an uncenny setting for a story with questionable morals. That's what you find here as well.

The gameplay supports the story and the story supports the emotions and mood the game tries to offer you. It's one of these "light horrors" stories where even nightmarish images are covered by gorgeous and funny pixel art that won't try to disgust you or make you feel uncomfortable. I'm not sure if it's a good gift for an 8+ kid, especially since you have to read quite a lot, but I don't think you need to look at this as a game "not smart enough" for adults. Quite contrary.

It starts pretty basic, but after some time you find more and more characters that are fun to interact and puzzles which are not easy enough to make you feel embarassed, but also not difficult enough to annoy you. The pacing of the game allows you to relax and enjoy yourself. The multiple endings are impressive, especially since they are not based on your single decision closed in a textbox as much as they are a result of your actions and wit.

It's a small game, but a one that required a lot of heart and became a great choice for a lonely evening, especially during the Halloween season. I highly recommend it.

35784651.review:
Solid little horror adventure, wishlisted it on a whim months ago because it looked like a gem and lo-and-behold, it was!

The characters are well written and most of them have their own little mini-quests, and the overall story and lore of the castle is nice.

Likewise, the puzzles, while not particularly hard, are still well-designed, and it's a nice touch that the game gives you some freedom in what order you tackle them.

The enemies are a bit disappointing though, basically just the Amnesia-style "run away if you see one" sort of deals, and the resource managment of candles/coins/health items seemed a bit too forgiving at times.

Still, if you'd like a top-down pixel take on survival/horror with a puzzle focus, it's definitely worth your time.

8.7/10

35763741.review:
The Count Lucanor is a game inspired by earlier Zelda and Silent Hill games. With an interesting story and great pixel art it is safe to call it one of the best pixelated horror/adventure games in recent years.

The game features an impressive cast of interesting characters, and is a nice blend of adventure and horror packed into one short little game with 5 different endings, which gives the game some replay value to it.

While it is a challenge to make a pixelated horror game with an over-head point of view truly scary, Baroque Decay has done a great job making the game wicked and disturbing by having great enemy designs, a nice use of lighting as well as simple yet effective animations and sound design. 

An overall simple but great indie title I advise you to pick up, can't wait to see what Baroque Decay comes up with next!

35763388.review:
DISCLAIMER: THIS ISN'T A BAD GAME.
(Tl;dr below)
First off, I'd like to praise this game for it's art and music. 

The visuals were really nice and cute, however it feels very limited (as many games with pixel art do). Almost as if they drew it out really nicely and redid it with pixels to match the overworld. I think they would've had more freedom if they'd stray from the pixel art style, but it was all great nonetheless.


They're music was the main reason I wanted this game. It sounds so nostalgic and makes me feel like I'm seven again. It's weird, I know, but that's how it honestly felt. Not a lot of people will agree with me on this, but I hope you find something in the music.



Now, what I dislike about this game is the save system.

It sounds like such a small thing, but it was enough for me to make me check 'no' in the 'Do you reccomend this game?' section. The saving system makes you sacrifice a coin in order to save your game, which sounds like such a big deal because coins are very valuable in the first parts of the game. I don't want to spoil a lot here, but the coins don't even matter in the long run unless you have a set amount to spare. It got so bad that I had to stop playing and just watch someone else play it on youtube. 




Tl;dr: If you have very little patience, this game may not be for you.

35752368.review:
Even with this simplistic pixel style, the horror vibe is very much there.  I found myself wincing at ever step in some rooms, wondering if this individual was lying or going to kill me.  The puzzles are challenging, and the entire castle encourages exploration, but if you do not have the right information going into the room, it will punish you without mercy.  I thought it was going to be a childish romp.  I didn't think I was going to have to keep lights on for fear of getting stolen away into nothingness.  Now I hate goats, old people, man-pigs, and I still am afraid of Big Blue Meanies from the Yellow Submarine.  I still like ravens.  Even when they peck your eyes out.  Trust no one.  If you have trust issues, this game is for you.

The music's tone is a bit grating to me, so I recommend turning it down to more managable settings.  The sound effects are crucial to your movement, and expertly used.  The whispers...the spoopty-ness.  Donkey!  Why did you leave me?!

Set yourself on fire and die!  Don't eat the apples.  You don't need them as much as you need a savepoint.

8/10

The music...it nearly killed it for me.  Less midi sound, please.  I know it's a stylized game, but do not...DO NOT skimp on the OST quality.  Everything else was a 10/10.  Beautiful Brothers Grimm style story.  Fantastic character roster.  The puzzles blew me away.  Screw goats.

35577014.review:
Before the Review:
The first thing I'm gonna point out I was going into this game completely blind.  I hadn't heard of it, or watched the trailer, I just snagged it in a humble bundle.  But unlike some of the games I've gotten on humble bundle, I knew I was going to want to play this one, and man did this game deliver.  Whether you find this game on humble bundle or not (Humble Gems Bundle 2, which still has 5 days left as of my writing this review), this game is a must buy.

Graphics and Animation:
I've played pixel art games before, but I've never seen them with pixel animated cutscenes.  Those alone are worth the price of admission.  It only makes me wish legacy game developers had tried it before.  How have I never seen that?  I played a lot of legacy games, but their pixel animation was always pretty minimalistic, like using slide effects, and slight movements like an averted gaze, or a smile, but this game goes balls to the wall with its cutscene animation.  I've never seen anything like it.

Story:
The game feels like a fable the whole way through.  It very much feels like a fable in the prologue, but when it switches it up after that (again, I played this completely blind), it just goes straight into Grimm's Fairy Tale territory.  I haven't finished getting all the achievements for this game yet (missing just a few now), but I'm gonna get 'em all.  And I'm probably gonna wind up streaming this game, too.

Everything Else:
This game has atmosphere down pat.  It really makes you appreciate the little things, like the wind blowing as you approach the merchant on the mountain on your way to the cemetary in the game's prologue.  They did a rather surprising amount of world building for such a short period of the game, and when it transitions to the main game, it's every bit as dark and spooky as you'd hope.  You literally can't see ANYTHING without a candle, which you have to place strategically as you collect them, in order to avoid getting attacked by servants.  I honestly love this mechanic, and I'm surprised I've never seen it before, either.

Verdict:
It's so good, it's so good, gawd, it's so good.  Buy it, AND PLAY IT.  Whether you get it in a humble bundle or not, make sure this game doesn't sit, unplayed and idle, in your library.  It deserves your time.

35563037.review:
The Count Lucanor is a short horror game with exploration and puzzle elements thrown into the mix. It starts off a bit slow, but picks up the pace soon enough. I managed to finish it in about four hours, but I plan on playing it over once or twice more to see what all I missed in my first play-through, and to get all of the achievements.

I enjoyed the game for its great music, beautiful cut-scenes comprised of wonderfully-crafted pixel art, its sort of "minimalist" art style, its nice story and twists, and for its legitimate moments of fright and terror without the garbage that is so often associated with the horror genre. On the flip side, I found some of the puzzles to be incredibly obtuse, thought several of the clues to be seemingly useless (I resorted to trial and error to guess a few), found some of the dialogue to be unnatural (I suspect the game was not originally in English), and the game froze and crashed a few times. These flaws do not outweigh the enjoyment I experience while playing though.

In short, I enjoyed this game and recommend others to check it out.

35503641.review:
Baroque Decay adlı indie bir grubun bizlere sunduğu güzel oyun. The Count Lucanor (Kont Lucanor) piksel grafiklere sahip RYO, macera, açık dünya ve puzzle türündeki oyunu. Ekibin şuana kadar ki ilk ve tek oyunu. Bu tarz kaliteli oyunları oynamak beni mutlu ediyo.

 Görselleri göze hitap etmese bile hikayesi ile beğenimi bir hayli kazandı. Basit bir hikaye ama insanın merak duygusunu tetikliyo ve oyunu keyifli hale getiriyor. 5 farklı sona sahip. Aldığımız kararlar oyunun gidişatını değiştiriyor. Kesinlikle aldığınız kararlar doğrultusunda oyunu bir kez bitirin. Ardından farklı sonlarını kayıt dosyasından geri alıp bakabilirsiniz. Bunun yanı sıra oyun direk Türkçe olarak başlıyor. Hoşuma gitmeyen tek özelliği kaydetme özelliğiydi. Oyunda kayıt noktasını çok sonra keşfettiğimde iş işten geçmişti. Spoiler olmadığını düşünüyorum çünkü oyun size nasıl kaydedileceğini söylemiyor ancak yinede spoiler metin olarak yazmaya karar verdim. Jogo excelente. Os gráficos pixelados são bem charmosos e bem desenhados, principalmente os personagens. A ambientação e a iluminação pelas velas no castelo também são muito bem implementadas, o jogo tem um clima de tensão muito bom, aumentado ainda mais pelos elementos de horror. Os puzzles são legais de se completar, embora grande parte seja relativamente fácil e o jogo forneça muitas dicas sobre como completar, o que não é um ponto negativo, é bem melhor do que jogos de dificuldade frustrante. A mecânica de ajudar ou não os NPCs é bem legal também.

35448223.review:
I recommend this with one reservation, particularly the fact that it is a short game, and I personally don't think it's worth almost $10. It's more appropriately priced on sale at $5 or below, which is more or less what I paid for it in a Humble Bundle. Other than that, I thought it was a great little game. I read all the negative reviews before I purchased it, as I always do. Many were insightful and well written but ultimately, more or less, wrong. 

I've been itching to replay the original King's Quest games, and have so far been frustrated and disappointed. DosBox just doesn't work well. So, as someone who appreciates that game, I feel like it compares well to this one, and it helped scratch a long standing itch. It's weird, quirky, dark, and interesting. It's not particularly difficult, and the characters aren't multi dimensional (a common complaint in the negative reviews) BUT why someone is looking for fully fleshed out characters in a short, pixelated, adventure game is beyond me. Personally, the characters were done well enough to carry the story forward, and, as I was more interested in that, they were good enough for me. 

I think it also compares well to Loom, which was also a great, if not short, adventure game. I know neither of those games were mentioned as the developers inspiration, but I couldn't help but feel a similarity between them, especially in the story aspects I personally appreciated. If you've liked either Loom or King's Quest, then I'd say definitely give it shot if it's on sale.

35403826.review:
Overall enjoyable and pleasantly surprising. Has the feel of a Flash RPG bred with a rogelike dungeon crawler. The story is engaging in a quaint sort of way, the gameplay is challenging without being a total slog. I was genuinely spooked a few times and felt a sense of accomplishment after beating this game. 

The cutscenes are great. The in game graphics are about as stripped down as you can get. The puzzles are interesting, if formulaic. I love the save mechanic. The prologue is so annoyingly pedestrian there's probably a link to TVTropes hidden somewhere. The endings are lackluster. Everything inbetween draws you into a game you'd expect to be playing on Newgrounds ten years ago. 

I bought it in a bundle, but would have gotten it alone if I'd known I was in for a childrens story drenched in gore, regret, and lost innocence.

35381515.review:
Мрачная сказка с поучительными концовками созданная под вдохновением испанской книги басен Tales of Count Lucanor.
В одной деревушке, жили мальчик Ганс с мамой. Жили они бедно и одним чудесным денем Ганс решил бросить все и отправиться на поиски сокровищ и славы.
Той же ночью, он встречает духа в лесу и следует за ним. Дух приводит его к замку и обещает мальчику несметные сокровища, но есть одно условие, Ганс должен угадать имя духа.Тут и начинаются жуткие и удивительные злоключения десятилетнего мальчика.
Принятые решения Гансом в ходе своего приключения, могут как облегчить, так и значительно усложнить дальнейшее прохождение. Помочь ли бедной старушке? Подать ли остатки своих монет попавшему в трудную ситуацию торговцу? Остановить безумца или отправить его на верную гибель в угоду получения части головоломки? Выбор зависит только от вас.
Весь игровой процесс происходит в замке, где герою необходимо будет решать загадки, прятаться от кровожадных стражей и попутно собирать буквы из имени того самого Духа. Единственное безопасное место это будет сад замка, где можно перевести дух и сохраниться. В The Count Lucanor весьма необычный подход к сохранению игры. Для того, что бы записать прогресс необходимы собирать золотые монеты, количество которых ограничено. Но, тут ничего страшного, если в начале игры у нас очень ограниченный запас золото, то ближе к середине это не будет проблемой.
Звуковое сопровождение в игре состоит из малоизвестных произведений Баха, что добавляет игре некую оригинальность и идеально подходит к происходящему на экране.
Многие игру сравнивают с Undertale, но это не верно.Игра своим обилием расчлененки и безумием скорее напоминает Yume Nikki от Kikiyama. С Undertale тут общего, разве что пиксельная графика.
Любителям хорроров и адвенчур очень рекомендую поиграть в эту страшную сказку на ночь. Думаю она не оставит вас равнодушными,более того может и помочь сделать какие-то выводы.

В общем я ставлю игре 10 из 10 , а играть в нее или нет решать только вам.

34297031.review:
The Count Lucanor is like those old German folk tales about kids encountering mythical beasts and magical people after leaving home; facing the consequences of their childish actions and desires in often grim ways.  Much like those old tales as well, The Count Lucanor takes an ordinarily tame and whimsical story and injects it with a lot of mature violence and unsettling imagery.  If you think of Hansel and Gretel or Little Red Riding Hood, you'll know that these stories meant for children can actually be quite dark despite their innocent profiles.  Taking this concept of juxtaposing lightheartedness and ghoulish tragedy is what gave those stories their identity, and The Count Lucanor succeeds in crafting a short tale around these themes that is often as frightening as it is playful.

The story revolves around Hans, a poor boy living in the countryside alone with his mom, as his dad left to fight in the war.  On the day of his 10th birthday, he becomes fed up with being poor when his mom can't afford presents or a cake for him, so he decides to leave home for good and enters the forest behind their home to look for adventure and riches.  Night soon falls however, and Hans finds that the forest has become a sort of nightmare version of itself, as the streams run with blood and once-ordinary goats now stand on their hind legs with murder in their eyes.  He eventually makes his way through the horrors and comes upon a quaint blue kobold (Spirit) who leads him to an old castle.  The kobold then tells him that if he can guess his name then he will become the successor to Count Lucanor and inherit the Count's castle and vast fortune.  

From there, the game settles into its adventure with light puzzles and mysteries to piece together.  Your goal is to gather envelopes scattered around the castle which each contain a letter of the kobold's name.  Along the way you uncover secrets, gather helpful items, and avoid the numerous traps and dangerous denizens of the castle.  You can't attack, and instead must rely on candles which you can hold and set down to light the way and give you some early warning before bumping into a horror in the dark.  The game world opens up in the castle, but much of the side quests and discoveries come naturally in your pursuit of the envelopes, and it all feels very focused and purposeful.  You meet people along the way who have their own place in your quest and who give insights into your journey, and uncover revelations that the castle holds without feeling like your playtime is being artificially lengthened with trivial chores or aimless wandering.

Overall, The Count Lucanor is tried and true Brothers Grimm folklore, and nails the tone and atmosphere one would expect from such works.  From the expressive pixel art to the soundtrack which evokes a gothic fairytale, the game feels faithful to its inspirations.  Along with its brisk pacing and satisfying, though easy, puzzles, there's rarely a dull moment in this charming and macabre adventure.  It all can be experienced in an evening, and despite its brief length, leaves a lasting impression with its earnest efforts and carefully crafted storybook dressings.

Truly a work of art!
The story is beautifully handcrafted, the characters are very intriguing and the scenario is wonderful.
The game mechanics are original but of course there are some recurring rpg/puzzle patterns.
The AI of some monsters could use some work.
I especially liked the care that was put in the small details, such as the saving system and the (really really nice) graphics.
Some minor elements could be improved such as AI and the final chapter of the story could be a little longer, but overall i enjoyed the game quite a lot and it delivers a grotesque scenario in many unexpected ways.

The story, the characters and the graphics are what make this game an enjoyable experience.
If this game was expanded into something bigger it would be a wonderful thing. 9/10

33221664.review:
类型为黑暗戏谑童话风的小品ADV，贯彻小孩人小不懂事需要梦魇来相随的成人正义。类似风格的作品一般在我们岛国同人界较为常见，并且通常都会组成以RPG Maker厂牌为主的罐头发布，它们或免费或以爱为名相互赠与，总之套路化量产化难以避免。
话说回来，这类游戏大多都有一个致命缺点，由于篇幅限制，剧情往往趋于简单，缺乏明显的格局感和层次感，在这点上本作也没有那么地例外。深度不够音效来凑，游戏吓人的地方还是有的，阶级讽刺也是有的。
简单的剧情，简明的道理，简洁的对白，人物善恶两端、黑白分明。这样的安排，女性朋友们会喜欢，小朋友看到会吓尿，男性如我不可描述。

33196202.review:
amazing game. there's about 9-10 hours worth of gameplay if you want to do everything, but in all honesty i wish it was longer. some of the things i liked:

- the whole fairytale premise felt unique and worked really well with the horror elements 
- the puzzles aren't too difficult but are engaging enough to keep you playing 
- the horror parts of the game are genuinely creepy and the game makes use of certain game mechanics to create atmosphere without going overboard 
- the characters and storyline are compelling and make you want to discover the truth behind them
- the use of comedy ties really well with the horror side to create a sense of dark humour

i have only a few complaints, but they're minor enough that i don't feel as if they detract from the overall experience. i can't recommend this game enough.

クリアしたので報告として。多分エンディングの中でも最短のエンディングでクリアしたんじゃないかな？
プレイ時間:2時間　実績:50%

感想
　ゲームを彩っているドットですが、本当に素晴らしいです。しかもそれがアニメーションとして動くので更に凄い。とくにアニメーション中のハンスくん(主人公)が可愛らしい。個人的に思うにはこども好きや、ショタフェチの人にオススメです。
　他にはダークな世界観がいいと思いますね。まぁ、それは私の趣味の範囲なのですが、序盤の明るい世界との対比が、後の暗い世界での探索を更に暗く感じさせます。
　後は個性的な魅力があるキャラクター達ですね。彼らのおかげで暗い世界がよく表現されていると思います。個人的にはヤギ飼いの人が好きですね。

とにかく、セール中だろうとセール外だろうとおすすめです。ゲームのサウンドトラックも付くのでゲームミュージックが好きな方にもおすすめですね。このレビューが少しでも参考になれば幸いです。

31536116.review:
Little scares with lots of heart, The Count Lucanor is a short, but satisfying game about a boy named Hans who goes out into the world seeking his fortune. However, he ends up getting more than maybe he bargins for when he gets thrown into a nightmarish world. You have to help Hans solve some simple puzzles while exploring a cursed castle in order to free yourself and hopefully obtain riches to save your family from poverty. Don't expect a lot out of the game mechanics or puzzles, but enjoy the story and atmosphere. The game does a really good job setting the story's tone, injecting it with humor and horror. It is very reminiscent of fairy tales and moral stories, and the artwork is quite nice. The overall game artwork is simple, but effective for what it wants. The music is charming and fits the overall theme of the game.

Pros:
+ Nice story
+ Achieveable achievements - Not too hard to get, but not so easy you'd get them right away
+ Some replayability, but it's not terribly in-depth
+ Pleasing pixel art
+ Atmospheric music
+ Just spooky enough

Cons:
- I can only play it in safe mode and it crashes if I try to tab out; doesn't work with Steam overlay, at least for me
- Some of the dialogue feels out of place/anachronistic, but that's only me being nit-picky
- A bit on the shorter side, with a relatively small map
- Could have had some better sound effects, but again, that's me being nit-picky

Overall, I would highly recommend this game if you are looking for a short diversion with a horror and fairy tale flair. All my cons are pretty negligible, in my opinion and should not dissuade you from trying it out if you like this genre and the art style. This game definitely isn't for everyone! People seeking difficult puzzles or hardcore scares will not find them here. This game is about discovering this world! I will be honest, this is exactly my cup of tea and I knew right away I would adore this game.

31531653.review: This game is wonderful.  The game world is full of surprises and discoveries.  Every corner contains something new.

31374820.review:
Inspiriert von Zelda und Silent Hill sagt die Spielbeschreibung.
Aber was tut man, wenn man beide Franchises nicht spielt? (Schande über mein Haupt)

Ganz einfach, man kauft sich im Sale spontan ein Spiel und schaut blindlings drauf los, ob es einem doch gefällt.
Und ja, ich war dann doch positiv überrascht.
:
:
:
Ein Junge nimmt reißaus aufgrund seines enttäuschenden Geburtstages, nach kurzen Abschnitten welche die Spielmechanik im Groben erläutern, kann der Albtraum auch schon losgehen.
Die charmante, bunte Pixelwelt wird auf einmal blutig und düster, die zerlegten Gliedmaßen überraschen dann doch sehr ;-)
Ein kleiner blauer Kobold weist einem den Weg in ein Schloss, das Schloss des namensgebenden Grafen.
Die Aufgabe  ist es den Namen des Koboldes zu erraten um sich einer Audienz beim Grafen persönlich als würdig zu erweisen.
Hinter den farblich gekennzeichneten Türen im Schloss verstecken sich Rätselpassagen die es zu lösen gilt, am Ende wartet fast immer einer der begehrten Buchstaben.

Mehr möchte ich an dieser Stelle auch gar nicht zum Gamepla schreiben, das Entdecken ist nämlich der wohl wichtigste Aspekt des Spieles und der Atmosphäre.
Ich war nie ein Horror-Spieler, selbst die F2P Version von Slender würde bei mir Traumata erzogen.
Count Lucanor ist da eine willkommene Abwechslung, der Horror und Grusel ist definitiv allgegenwärtig, Pixeloptik sei dank aber niemals seelenfressend intensiv.
Die Rätsel sind auch nicht gerade knackig wie bei einem Lucas Arts Spiel.
So steht das Spiel meiner Meinung nach etwas zwischen den Stühlen.
Horrorfreunde werden eher lächeln, Rätselfans lösen es mit geschlossenen Augen.

Für mich ist es jedoch eine willkommene Abwechslung. Wenn man zu anfällig für starken Horror ist und einem kopfzerbrechende Rätsel zur Weißglut treiben, sollte man Count Lucanor ruhig eine Chance einräumen.
Die Präsentation ist stimmig, die Story nimmt ein, zwei Bögen und es gibt zig alternative Enden für Komplettisten.
Unter dem Strich trübt lediglich der Preis etwas das Vergnügen.
Wenn man tatsächlich nur einen Durchlauf spielt, ist der Abspann nach gut 3h erreicht.

Eine Empfehlung spreche ich dennoch aus, der Charme und Idee hinter dem ganzen machen so einiges wieder Wett.

(Achja, die SPeilfigur bewegt sich nervtötend langsam, das verhagelt es manchmal schon ein wenig ;-) )

31200500.review:
[h1]The Count Lucanor İncelemesi	[/h1] 

[u]Bugün Onuncu Yaş Günüm.Keşke Babamda Olsaydı Burada.Ama Neyse Annem Bana Doğum Günü Pastası Yapmıştır.Eve Girdim.Annem Oldukça Normal Görünüyordu , Acaba Doğum Günümü Unutmuşmudur ?.Sordum Ona Doğum Günümü Unuttun Mu Diye.Bana 'Tabiki Unutmadım Hans' Dedi.Bende Ona 'O Zaman Pasta Nerede' Diye Sordum.Bana 'Biliyorsun Baban Savaşa Gitti , O Gittiğinden Beri Durumumuz İyi Değil , Sadece Çorba Yapabildim' Dedi.Sinirlenmiştim.Evden Gitmeye Karar Verdim.Annem Çok Üzüldü Ama Evden Ayrılmama İzin Verdi.'[/u]    

[b]The Count Lucanora Hoşgeldiniz.Oyunun Giriş Bölümünden Bir Bölümü Anlattım Sizlere.Oyun 2016 Yılının Mart Ayında Çıkmış.Oyun Hakkında Hiç Bir Bilgim Olmadı.Zaten Oyunu Yapan Firmayıda İlk Defa Duyuyorum.Bir Arkadaşım Oyunu Türkçeye Çevirdiğini Söyledi.Benimde Türkçe Dil Desteği Olan Oyunlara Bir Zaafım Var Tabii.Oyuna Baktım Çok Beğendim Aldım.İyiki Almışım Arkadaşlar.[/b] 

[b]Öncelikle Oyunun Müzikleri Ve Grafikleri Hakkında Konuşmak İstiyorum.The Count Lucanor Gibi 2D Oyunların Grafiklerinden Çok Fazla Şey Beklememek Lazım.Ama Yapanda Yapıyor Hani.Oldukça Güzel Grafikleri Var Oyunun.Müzikleride Bu Türün Müziklerinin Çok Üstünde.The Count Lucanor Grafik Ve Müziklerde Ortalamanın Çok Üstünde.	[/b] 

[b]Oyuna Beni En Çok Bağlayan Şüphesiz Hikayesi Oldu Arkadaşlar.Spoiler Vermeden Hikayeyi Anlatayım.Karakterimiz Hans'ın Onuncu Doğum Günü Gelmiştir.Hans Doğum Günü Pastası Ve Hediye İstemektedir.Ama Annesi Fakir Oldukları İçin Bu İsteğini Gerçekleştiremez.Hans Sinirlenir Ve Evden Ayrılıp Macera Avına Çıkmaya Karar Verir.Anneside Üzelsede Kabul Eder (Hangi Anne Buna İzin Verir Ki ?).Hans Maceraya Çıkar Ve Yolda Bir Şato Görür.Şatonun İçinde Bir Cinle Karşılaşır.Cin Hans'a Bir Sınava Gireceğini Ve Geçerse Bu Şatonun Sahibi Olabileceğini Söyler Ve Hans Sınavı Geçmeye Çalışır.Devamı Spoiler Olacağı İçin Hikayeyi Burada Kesiyorum.Hikayenin Bütünlüğünün Sağlanabilmesi İçin Etrafa Notlar , Eşyalar Yerleştirmişler.Oyunun Başında Bizim İçin Hiç Bir Anlam İfade Etmesede Oyun İlerledikçe Hepsinin Büyük Bir Anlamı Oluyor.Hikaye Olabildiğince Az Ana Ve Yan Karakterle Desteklenmiş , Eğer Fazla Karakter Olsaydı.Bütünlük Sağlanamayacaktı[/b]      

[b]Oyunun Birden Fazla Sonu Var Arkadaşlar.3 Tanesini Gördüm.Bunlardan 1 Tanesi Çok Kötüyken , Diğer İkisi Oldukça Güzeldi.Oyunun Son Sahnesinde Yapacağınız Hareket Sonları Etkiliyor.Bu Sayede Oyundaki Sonların Birçoğunu Görme Şansınız Oluyor.[/b] 

[b]Diyaloglar Oldukça Hoş.10 Yaşındaki Bir Çocuğun Konuşabileceği Gibi Yazılmış Hans'ın Replikleri.Güzel Ve Herkese Hitap Edebilecek Komik Esprilerde Bulunmakta.[/b] 

[b]Oynanışa Gelirsek Oyunda Çoğunlukla Kimi Yerlerde Harf Mektubu , Kimi Yerlerde Altın Bir Mühür  Arıyoruz.Amacımız Odalarda Gezip Bu Tür Şeyler Bulup , Oyunda İlerlemek.Oynanış Sade Gelebilir Ama Kesinlikle Öyle Değil.Küçük Bulmacalar Ve Bazı Olaylarla Desteklenmiş Oynanış.6 Saat Boyunca Hiç Sıkılmadan Oynadım Oyunu.Oyunda Otomatik Save Sistemi Yok.Etrafta Çeşmeler Arıyoruz.Bu Çeşmeleri Bulunca Buraya 1 Altın Sikke Atıp Oyunu Kaydedebilirsiniz.[/b] 

[b]Oyunu 4 Bölüme Ayırabiliriz.Birinci Bölümümüz Giriş Bölümünde Hans Macera Aramaya Başlar Ve Şatoyu Bulur.İkinci Bölümümüzde Hans Şatoda Harf Mektupları Aramaya Başlar.Üçüncü Bölümümüzde 'Hademe' Adı Verilen Yaratıklar Şatoda Devriye Gezmeye Başlar Ve Oyun Burada Macera Türünden Korku/Gerilim Türüne Kaymaya Başlar.Dördüncü Bölümümüzde Hans Yeraltında Mahsur Kalır , Yerüstüne Çıkmak İçin Yollar Arar.Tüm Gerçekler Burada Açığa Çıkar.[/b]
 
[i]The Count Lucanor Hayatım Boyunca Kolay Kolay Unutamayacağım Bir Oyun Oldu.Oynadığım Oyunlar Arasından En İyilere Girdi Bile.Ölmeden Önce Alıp Oynamalısınız. [/i]

30951336.review:
[h1]Silent Hill в шкуре Undertale?[/h1]

[i]На момент написания данного мнения, 100% обзоров от русскоязычного сообщества положительны![/i]
А ведь так не должно быть, ведь если трезво оценивать данный проект, то он больше напоминает  демо-версию потенциально хорошей игры. 

Но обо всем по порядку, и начнем, пожалуй, с [u]плюсов[/u] данного творения:
 + Атмосфера. Путешествие по мрачному замку и в правду изрядно интригует, и, по большому счету, это чувство не покинет вас при первом прохождение так точно.
 + Звук и музыка. Звуковое сопровождение, как по мне, со своей задачей справилось. Где нужно оно расслабляло игрока, давая ему передохнуть, где нужно погружало в атмосферу отчаяния и беспомощности.
 +- Пара неплохих игровых находок (к примеру, система сохранений).
 +- Неплохая пиксельная графика с анимированнами сценками. Но отнести это к полноценному плюсу сложно, поскольку далеко не всем такая графика придется по вкусу, да и сценки появляются на экране довольно редко и длятся пару-тройку секунд. 

Далее перейду к тому, о чем [u]стоит задуматься[/u] перед покупкой данной игры.
 - Головоломки. Тут они прям ну очень простые, сводятся либо к найди предмет и юзани его, либо спрячься/пробеги вовремя. [spoiler]Проблемы могут возникнуть только при прохождение без сбора букв[/spoiler]
 - Монстрики. Из-за того что они не блещут интеллектом, вскоре понимаешь, что имея в рюкзаке огромный запас провизии, можно просто ранить игру, без каких либо последствий для себя. К тому же, разнообразием они вас также не порадуют, в игре их всего 4 вида.
 - Продолжительность. Из-за своей "сложности" игра проходится за 3-4 часа.
 - Персонажи. Большинство NPC в игре - это бездушные, плохо прописанные плохиши, которым всучили по одной [b]особенности[/b] [spoiler](Человеко-свин, обманщик-купец, кровожадная голова)[/spoiler], дабы игроку их образы врезались в память. Но одно дело, если у тебя не вызывают интереса второстепенные роли, то другое, когда ты не можешь сопереживать главному герою. Ведь, по сути, он ребенок, который постоянно что-то требует и капризничает, и ассоциировать себя с ним проблематично. 
 - Сюжет. Сама завязка у игры выглядит как бессмыслица, в которую сложно поверить. Ведь какая мать отпустит единственного ребенка неведомо куда, при этом оставшись одна? Но бог с завязкой, ведь некоторые сюжетные повороты сделаны "потому что гладиолус". "Я возьму червяка с собой! Зачем? ... Вдруг пригодится!". Тоже самое и с моралью, здесь она проста, но подана настолько неряшливо, что у тебя  все равно остается ощущение, что семья семьей, а деньжата-то поважнее.
 - Концовки. Их напихали по принципу "больше значит лучше", но к сожалению это так не работает. По сути можно было оставить две, и ничего бы от этого не изменилось. 

Такое ощущение, что авторы подразнили нас плакатом "мы могем, но в меру!". Нельзя назвать игру откровенно плохой, но для меня она больше напоминает выпускную работу кучки программистов, нежели полноценный проект. Я взял игру при скидке в -50%, чего вам не советую, ждите лучшего предложения!

10/10

30942667.review:
[i]The Count Lucanor[/i] is a pixelated fairy tale that ties together a classical narrative with a modern mindset and a healthy dose of gothic horror. I think it's so fresh and yet just right for these fairy tale archetypes to finally be gamified: the fool who goes out seeking fortune, the strangers on the road asking for help who will obviously come in handy later on, the trickster archetype whose every word is called into doubt. It makes me wonder why more games aren't drawing from the same reference pool. Rather than saving the world or your kidnapped wife, the premise of the game is that your character, the fool child Hans, has stumbled into the Castle Tenebre, where he has to undergo a trial in order to inherit the eponymous Count Lucanor's fortune. The trial in question? He has to guess the name of the Count's manservant, a blue kobold.

I generally dislike when smaller budget games refuse to focus on one aspect of their experience as being the center of the game's enjoyability, trying to achieve AAA expansiveness but instead creating a shallow but wide set of experiences. [i]The Count Lucanor[/i] is one of the few indie games I've played that manages to juggle a lot of things very effectvely and still feel like a rich experience even though playing through, I can't imagine this game lasting more than 5 hours even with a lot of dawdling. This loops back to the particular setting and premise which the devs have chosen, which constrains the game so cleverly; the events of the game are even supposed to be happening all in one night, which feels perfectly attuned to the content that the player is given.

The puzzles of the game are excellently designed, not too difficult, and the adventure game aspect of "I have this problem it needs this item," is handled well in the sense that as soon as you have the item, you know exactly what it is for, and there is no inventory management fiddling. The horror aspect of the game never quite registered with me, the most scared I got being during [spoiler]the Library puzzle with the Camerlengo[/spoiler], but I would probably chalk that up to me being unfazed by most horror in video games. Also, you seem to be invincible as long as you're underneath a table. All in all, the mechanical aspects of the game are very strong. Stronger still in things the game chooses not to do, such as not having monsters in the puzzle rooms unless they're part of the puzzle [spoiler]except for the butt things, but they're slow and easily blocked into paths by pushable objects[/spoiler]. Some of it feels very new, like having to light your own way with semi-consumables. While some of it, like colored keys for colored doors, feels so oldschool that it's kind of endearing amidst everything else.

The visuals are mostly good. There are some well done cutscenes near the beginning and end of the game, and the sprites and their animation in the game proper are pretty decent (other than me noticing that Hans' walk cycle was broken in one of the rooms, and only that room for some reason). I feel the same about the music, sets the atmosphere well, it has cracks in places such as the awkward complete silence in the cutscene that plays [spoiler]when Hans falls into the depths[/spoiler]. The writing, I'm not so sure about. The anachronistic contemporary vernacular sometimes draws away from how seriously I can take the situation, most prominent in the very first conversation between Hans and his mother where he whines about birthday cake, and dotted around everywhere else from then on. Lines like [spoiler] "I'm scared sh*tless, Hans,"[/spoiler] do not actually make me feel more scared, they makes me feel like the situation is much sillier than it's supposed to be. But the game, I feel is fairly aware of how much silliness it has along with its creepiness, and so I'll mark it as a matter of taste. I doubt the game would be improved by the devs trying to imitate the way people speak in fairy tales. It's just, the game gives me a real Angela Carter vibe, yeah? And I wish it could be more that. The final series of twists are somewhat obvious, which is faithful to the feeling of the fairy tales the game imitates in a way, and anticlimactic in another. It's probably best not to think too deeply on the plot.


Enough of that TL;DR shiz. It's a good game. Maybe not mind shatteringly good, but definitely worth a play for anyone even remotely interested in it from looks alone. It doesn't disappoint.

30727771.review:
[h1]这是我成人以后看过的最像童话的故事。[/h1]
      大家玩到结局之前肯定都是以惊悚游戏的观感去看待这部游戏的。毋庸置疑，恐怖的配乐，如影随形的幽灵，穷追不舍的恶魔山羊，诅咒，血腥…太多这类元素了，我前期也是玩的脊背发凉。但是玩到结局回过味来，真的是这样么？到最后，人家想诉说的就是蓝魔的百年孤独，人家想传达的就是安贫乐道，母子之爱，和之前浓墨重彩描绘的的诡异血腥完全背道而驰。这种感觉就…很神妙，你突然发现这一切只是一个孤独而喜欢自我标榜的小蓝魔在完成已故的顽固主人的命令以得到自由，阴谋论完全不存在，甚至你可以自己选择接受不接受，那些历史只是些历史而已，眼前就是一个你耳熟能详的童话故事：“少年嫌弃家里贫穷离开母亲寻找宝藏，遇到蓝魔进入谜一样的城堡接受考验，最后凭借勇气和智慧来到了蓝魔面前，少年通过戒指看到了真实，蓝魔告知了“城堡是个禁锢，留下来就能永远富裕的真相”，但是少年毅然决定回家，陪伴母亲。“很好很强大……
      在这个故事里，好人有好报，坏人会得到相应的报应，最好的结局是回到自己的家并帮助可怜的蓝魔，太tm正能量了，选进天朝小学课本都没有问题。所以读到最后你会发现什么呢，发现“成人童话”真正的打开方式。不是充满黄暴，现实的重口味结局才是成人童话，成人的童话依然是童话，依然是善有善报，恶有恶报，只不过它可能装饰了一些成人才懂的黑色，让你心旌摇动一下，但纯粹的爱和善意是不会变的。
      玩完不禁感叹，想太多……

30502401.review:
终于通关啦，可以写评测啦。感谢谜之声（Sound of Mystery）的汉化~~

[h1]影音演出[/h1]
有的老外说画面很poor，我不赞同。
本作的画面质量放在pixel风格作品中算是上乘的。
路边一草一木、涓涓溪流、墙边裂痕、暗夜灯影、人物闲置时的一颦一笑，都做得很“真实”，画面风格整体上可以称为pixel风格的《巫师1 / 狩魔猎人1》
但音乐倒是真 · 粗糙。
我宁愿相信这种粗糙是刻意的，如同磁带音质与胶片颗粒影像放在现代依然有很多人喜欢。
然而，其配乐更大的问题是编曲本身……编曲就像逆着“流行乐”原则做成的一样。旋律和声混杂、无突出主题、无片段感、无节奏感，总的说——不便于哼唱与洗脑，存在感几乎为零。

[h1]剧情[/h1]
格林童话式的故事。
别有有心的玩家，可以从中读出白雪公主的乱伦元素、睡美人的强暴元素、美女与野兽的调教元素……这些都需要别有用心才能读到，但作品直接表现的画面与故事，论猎奇、论重口，比起来也是只高不低。
结局也是格林童话式的，简单、直接、有味。
常有人将本作与Undertale归为同类，但其实也不一样。本作的故事几乎是线性的，可错过的（missable）剧情虽然有，但也不多。收集完美癖的玩家也可以随意玩。

[h1]系统、机制、特色[/h1]
缺点有，但瑕不掩瑜。
主角走路极慢。
虽然也可以理解，走路慢，是为了强化主角的脆弱（似乎是受《寂静岭》《生化危机》的启发）
但……就不可以设定类似 [加速行路] 的可解锁作弊MOD么……一周目慢慢走，是沉浸体验；但三周目还必须慢慢走，就是折磨了。
另一个特色是蜡烛，谁用谁知道，各种意义上的神设定，堪比《生化危机 初代》的 “子弹当防御工具用” 的创意。照明、标记、诱敌、寻路，用处多多，游戏中没配有教程，允许了玩家自行发掘。强大的玩家甚至可以试试背板后全程摸黑通关。
至于主线任务，我就不多剧透了。只说，本作推进剧情的方式很有趣。

总的说，强烈推荐。

30500913.review:
El Conde Lucanor brinda lo que promete. Es un juego que no te llevará muchas horas (las justas y necesarias), con la posibilidad de rejugarlo debido a los distintos finales y opciones dentro del juego. 
 Para los amantes de los juegos retro, ésta, es una excelente opción tanto por el arte cómo por la música. 
 
La historia es atrapante, aunque puede resultar predecible en varios momentos. En este título interpretas el papel de Hans, un niño de 10 años que cansado de su vida pobre, decide irse de aventura. No muy lejos, las cosas comenzarán a dar un giro inesperado y se verá atrapado en el Castillo del Conde Lucanor, donde deberá atravezar varias pruebas mortales.

 El juego en sí ofrece varios puzzles de lógica bastante simples pero efectivos, no hay sistema de combate ya que como en otros títulos similares, el protagonista deberá escapar y esconderse en lugar de enfrentar a sus enemigos (lo cual esta muy bien ya que juegas como un niño de 10 años contra monstruos grotescos).

En definitiva, "The Count Lucanor", es un juego recomendable que deja con ganas de más, no porque le falte, sino porque el concepto es muy bueno y se puede explotar aún más con secuelas o juegos similares.

30476045.review:
A solid 3-to-5-hour dark fantasy adventure game that doesn't outstay its welcome.  Riffs on Silent Hill and Zelda.  Highly interactive gameplay with lots of secrets and five endings.  Some surprisingly unsettling subject matter complimented by great sound design.  Music is NES-styled chiptunes of horror ambience and classical chamber and Boroque music (unsure, but it might be Bach). The Spanish team aimed for Ghibli, and I think with cutscenes, the main character, and some subject matter, they nailed the aesthetic.  Supporting characters don't look so hot, but oh well.

The worst thing about it is the tired pixel-art style.  Also, enemy pathing can be a bit janky, but interacting with enemies is not a huge part of the game.  

I wouldn't pay 10, but I would recommend at the 5 dollars I paid for it.  Still on sale as of writing this review.

The best thing I can say about it is that it envokes nostalgia for then-childhood classics like Spirited Away, Return to Oz, Dark Crystal, NeverEnding Story, and Legend, while being suitably adult for now-adult players.
